content.introduction: The &crkeng; tools represent work by AltLab at U of Alberta and >e; at UiT.

This is the home page of the &coreng; parser project. The project is still in its embryonic phase. You will be able to analyse a handful of words only, but we will enlarge the base eventually. The parser is based upon the Single Written Form.

The &faoeng; tools combine a morphological and morphophonological transducer with the set of lexemes found in Føroysk orðabók into a grammatical parser for &faoeng;. The morphological coverage is quite good (with some lacunas for strong verbs and adjectives), but the syntactic analyser is in its infancy.
The &fineng; &aimeng;
The &fiteng; &aimeng;

This is the home page of the &ipkeng; parser project. The project is still in its embryonic phase. Our &ipkeng; analysers covers the basic inflectional grammar, and the central vocabulary (but very few derivational affixes!). We will enlarge the base eventually. We also offer a convertion from the Interactive IñupiaQ Dictionary encoding to Unicode.

This is one of the home pages of the &kaleng; parser project. Use this page if you want to analyse &kaleng; text, convert the Kleinschmidt orthography to modern orthography (known bug: û is not converted correctly, otherwise the converter should work), look at a translitteration of text, or if you just would like to read about the parser. The other homepage of this project is at Oqaasileriffik, where you will find a search interface for (unanalysed) text, and a very nice interface for word analysis and paradigm generation.
The infrastructure, language independent components and methodology behind the &kaleng; parser is the same as the one behind the Saami parsers documented elsewhere on these pages. Whatever language-independent information given on the Saami parsers should thus also hold for &kaleng;.
A new version of the &kaleng; spell checker and hyphenation tools for the Windows version of the MSOffice suite (KUKKUNIIAAT ver. 2.0) is now ready for download. It is free of charge and can be downloaded here.
The &koieng; analyser gives a morphological and syntactical analysis of most words in running text.
The &kpveng; analyser gives a morphological and syntactical analysis of most words in running text.
The &mhreng; analyser gives a morphological and syntactical analysis of most words in running text.
The &mnseng; analyser gives a morphological and syntactical analysis of most words in running text.
The &myveng; analyser gives a morphological and syntactical analysis of most words in running text.
The &rmfeng; analyser gives a morphological analysis of words in running text.
The &ruseng; analyser gives a morphological and syntactical analysis of most words in running text.
The &udmeng; analyser gives a morphological and syntactical analysis of most words in running text.
The &sjdeng; analyser only contains a handful of words yet. The number generator works, though.

The &sjeeng; analyser and generator currently work for most of the nouns and verbs found in the lexical database for Pite Saami (saami.uni-freiburg.de/psdp/pite-lex), which is regularly corrected, expanded and improved. This database is based on the Pitesamisk ordbok samt stavningsregler (Samica 2, 2016, edited by J. Wilbur), but also includes a few other words added by Ann-Charlotte Sjaggo. The orthography used is based on the orthography presented at saami.uni-freiburg.de/psdp/stavningsregler/. This is still a preliminary, test version, and is under on-going development.
For &smjeng;, our morphological tools are quite robust. Analysing words in context (disambiguation and syntax), however, is still in the beginning.
The &smneng; analyser gives the morphological analysis of over 92 % of the words in running text, and gives a rough syntactic analysis of sentences.
The &smseng; analyser gives the morphological analysis of over 70 % of the words in running text, but work has not yet started on syntactic analysis of sentences.
content.analysis_text: Analyse words (no syntactic analysis). You may paste in text, and the program gives all possible analyses for each wordform. You may also convert text from Interactive IñupiaQ Dictionary encoding to Unicode.
&adheng; The program also gives IPA representation, and it converts from Kleinschmidt (pre-1973) to modern orthography.
Analyse, disambiguate and hyphenate text, and give dependency analysis. Convert text into IPA.
Analyses text. Converts text between latin letters and syllabics.
content.paradigm_text: Generates paradigms of different sizes for any word.
Generates paradigms of different sizes for the core vocabulary.
Generates paradigms of different sizes for the core vocabulary.
The paradigm generator works formally, but the paradigms given often contain more errors than correct forms. At the moment, the generator is on the net for internal delvelopment purposes.
Generates paradigms of different sizes for the core vocabulary.
Generates paradigms of different sizes for adjectives, nouns and verbs.
Generates paradigms of different sizes for adjectives, nouns and verbs.
content.generator_text: Generates wordforms using lemma and grammatical tags.
content.numerals_text: Write a number (ex. 123), and get a number word.
Write a number (ex. 74), and get a number word.
content.nds_text: Interactive online dictionary. Understands inflected words and offers inflection paradigms. With corpus search.
content.webdictionaries_text: Look up words in an online web dictionary. The words are presented as a list, which can be useful if you don't know how to spell the word.
content.korp_text: Search for words and grammatical patterns in text collections (does not work in Internet Explorer).
content.placenames_text: Write placenames in Norwegian or Finnish, and get the corresponding place name in Saami, or vice versa.
content.risten_text: This is a development of the old risten.no
content.oahpa_text: Interactive programs for glossary and vocabulary training, and for practicing dialogues.
Interactive programs for glossary and vocabulary training, and for practicing number date and time expressions.
Interactive programs for glossary training, and for practicing number date and time expressions. The program is still just a demo version.
Interactive programs for glossary training, and for practicing number date and time expressions. The program is still just a demo version.
Interactive programs for glossary training, and for practicing number date and time expressions, with extensive morphology in verbs and nouns. The contextual practice is still much of a demo version.
content.crkoahpa_text: Interactive programs for glossary and vocabulary training, and for practicing number date and time expressions. This is a very restricted demo version.
content.tts_text: The computer reads the text to you.
content.gielese_text: Learn words – the program contains audio files and photos
content.visl_text: Interactive programs for training grammar skills.
content.mt: Machine Translation from North Saami to Norwegian
content.mt_text: Paste text or translate web pages.
content.mt2: Machine Translation between different Saami languages
content.mt2_text: Paste text or translate web pages. These programs are still on a beta stadium.
content.other: AltLab at U of Alberta and Giellatekno at UiT. AltLab work is financed by SSHRC Canada
The project is a joint project between Grønlands Sprognævn (Oqaasileriffik) and the University of Tromsø.
The Ingrian tools represent work by Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø
The project is a joint project between Grønlands Sprognævn (Oqaasileriffik) and the University of Tromsø.
The Khanty tools represent work by Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø
The Komi Permyak tools are in the making. They represent a joint project between FU-lab, Giellatekno and Jack Rueter.
The Komi tools are in the making. They represent a joint project between Giellatekno and Jack Rueter. The lexicon of the analysers are based upon Jack Rueter's Komi-Finnish-English dicionary.
The Livonian tools represent work by Renate Blumberga and Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø

The Moksha tools represent work by Eeva Herrala, Aleksandr Feoktistov, Merja Salo and Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The present work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø
The Meadow Mari tools are in the making. They represent a joint project between Giellatekno and Jorma Luutonen. The lexicon of the analysers are based upon Arto Moisios Mari-Finnish dicionary.
The Hill Mari tools represent work by Julia Kuprina and Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø
The Erzya tools are in the making. They represent a joint project between Giellatekno and Jack Rueter. The lexicon of the analysers are based on dictionary work on Erzya by many authors.
The Nganasan tools represent work by Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø
The Olonetsian tools represent work by Timo Rantakaulio and Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø
The work on the Finnish Romani tools has just started. The analysers are put here for testing purposes.
The work on the Kildin Saami tools has just started. The analysers are put here for testing purposes.

The Pite Saami tools are available here for testing purposes, and without any guarantee for accuracy. These are currently under development by Joshua Wilbur (with significant technical support from Giellatekno) as part of a project on Pite Saami syntactic structures at the Freiburg Research Group in Saami Studies. Thanks to Ann-Charlotte Sjaggo and Trond Trosterud for setting up the initial framework.
The Veps tools represent work by Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø

The Nenets tools represent work by Tapani Salminen, Sven-Erik Soosaar and Jack Rueter, in cooperation with Giellatekno. The present work is financed by the Kone Foundation and the University of Tromsø
